body:
### Issue

Consider the following three ex-mode commands:

1. `:syntax sync fromstart`
2. `:if 0 | syntax sync fromstart | endif`
3. `:if 0 | execute 'syntax sync fromstart' | endif`

I would expect that command (1) would sometimes be slow, but commands (2) and (3) should never be slow, since the conditional branch never executes. However, it seems that sometimes when command (1) is slow, command (2) is also slow. On the other hand, it seems that command (3) is always fast.

This issue also seems to affect try-catch blocks.

### Environment

- `nvim --version`: version 0.4.4
- `vim -u DEFAULTS` (version: 8.2.1522) behaves the same; see the corresponding vim [issue](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/7320).
- Operating system/version: NixOS 20.09
- Terminal name/version: st version 0.8.4
- `$TERM`: st-256color

### Steps to reproduce using `nvim -u NORC`

- Run `nvim -u NORC`.
- Create a large file by typing `iecho 'test'<ret><esc>999.`.
- Run command (1) above, `:syntax sync fromstart`. (Don't skip this step; at least on my system, skipping this step causes the error to not be reproduced.)
- Run command (2) above, `:if 0 | syntax sync fromstart | endif`.

The command should execute instantaneously (like command (3) does), but does not.

title: syntax sync slow even in non-executing conditional branch
